cons:
Career advancement can be difficult.
A big part of the departments are outsourced.

cons: The main Challenges were to insure the things that made Optus a good employer remained in place as these were the qualities that made our customers happy with Optus from day one.

title: ‘Great for short career stints but be prepared to be thrown into the deep end’

cons: Where do I start... Awful management, the WORST work/life balance I've experienced, brown nosing in all directions. Toxic atmosphere.

title: ‘Once a great place to work, no more’

Need to be Sydney based for career progression
cons: A very Sydney centric company that has lost its way over the past 3 years. Redundancies very 6-9 months, leaving less people to do the same work. Managements solution to increasing productivity- hire another layer of management to cover their own.

title: ‘A challenging time spent working all over the country for little acknowledgement.’

title: ‘I love working for Optus.’

Besides the awesome discounts you get as an Optus employee, there's alot more that come your way at the work place, which really drives engagement across the business. This is really a multi cultural work place and everyone's opinion is valuable.  The Melbourne Office is ideally located close to Flinders Street station with a lot of coffee shops and eateries around.
cons: Opportunities for career development would really vary depending on yourself, if you have a pretty niche skill set / interest then getting ahead may be a challenge. But in the end it all comes down to you and the relationships you build though out the business.

title: ‘Good place to work and your team often becomes your second family. Sometimes stressful but generally pretty rewarding’

title: ‘I would only recommend working here for the short-term as it is a flexible part-time opportunity for university students/parents. However, say goodbye to your weekends and social life. Be expected to work hard to achieve your targets otherwise you are loo’
pros:
The good things
- the team has always been pretty good - close knit and everyone is willing to help out. It is pretty common to have cliques (especially between stores) .
- you get a discounted phone plan for yourself and additional services.
- it is flexible to an extent- my manager has always been good in approving leave within limits (exam period for uni etc).
cons:
- As it is retail, expect to work every single saturday/sunday (being a part-timer). In this sense it isn't very flexible with social life. 
- Micromanagement by some managers.
- Constant changes in technology and plans/promotions (can be hard to keep up when you're juggling university).
- No work events besides the annual Christmas party that retail staff don't usually attend.
- The CUSTOMERS are probably the most challenging part of the job. If you do not enjoy irate, uncontrollable customers and confrontation, this job is not for you. 
- No real training- when you begin you do modules and you are thrown into the deep end to serve customers. In busy periods it is hard to get the aid of a senior assistant as they may be with their own customers.
- System errors- the new systems are always crashing- leaving the customer sometimes angry and impatient. 
- Sometimes the targets are not achievable and there is a lot of pressure from management.
- career advancement or promotion does not necessarily mean a payrise- you also have more responsibility on your shoulders.
